heading: Illuminating animation: Pat Hanrahan, Turing Award winner, revolutionizes photorealistic rendering in film and virtual realit
alt: A smiling man poses with his arms crossed in front of an array of electronic equipment.

body: Jeffrey Ullman, professor of computer science, 1987. Ullman was a corecipient of the 2020 A.M. Turing Award with his collaborator, Alfred Aho of Columbia University. The pair did seminal work in compilers and algorithms and influenced the entire field with their popular textbooks. Ed Souza/Stanford News Service.
heading: Foundations of computing: Jeffrey Ullman honored with A.M. Turing Award for groundbreaking contributions to compilers and algorithm
alt: A black and white image of a man with a full beard, wearing a tie, sitting at a desk.

body: A public art display called Pars pro Toto, created by artist Alicja Kwade, installed in the Science and Engineering Quad courtyard, 2021. The twelve spheres range in size from 16 to 98 inches and are made of stone sourced from eight countries. The work was selected by a committee of faculty, students, and staff appointed by Dean Jennifer Widom. Andrew Brodhead/Stanford University Communications.
heading: Artistry in science: Alicja Kwade's 'Pars pro Toto' installation enriches Stanford's Science and Engineering Quad with global inspiratio
alt: A landscaped campus courtyard featuring benches, large spherical sculptures, and trees.

body: Carpentry shop, early 1900s. Special Collections & University Archives.
heading: A glimpse inside Stanford's Carpentry Sho
alt: Old photograph depicting a busy carpentry workshop, featuring men in aprons engaged in work under bright windows.

body: Product Realization Lab, 2023. Andrew Brodhead/Stanford University Communications.
heading: Inside Stanford's Product Realization La
alt: Old photograph depicting a busy carpentry workshop, featuring men in aprons engaged in work under bright windows.

body: Exterior of the Mitchell Earth Sciences Building with signage to mark the launch of the Stanford Doerr School of Sustainability, 2022. The Mitchell Building is the administrative home of the school. Stanford News Service.
heading: New horizons in environmental education: Launch of the Stanford Doerr School of Sustainability at the Mitchell Earth Sciences Buildin
alt: A cyclist passes the Stanford School of Sustainability building.

body: Arun Majumdar, professor of mechanical engineering, who became the inaugural dean of the Stanford Doerr School of Sustainability, 2022. Stanford’s first new school in seventy years arose out of ideas submitted by Stanford faculty, students, staff, and alumni as part of a university-wide long-range planning process. The Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering became joint with the new school, which also includes the Stanford Woods Institute for the Environment and the Precourt Institute for Energy. Edward Caldwell.
heading: Forging a sustainable future: Arun Majumdar appointed inaugural dean of Stanford Doerr School of Sustainabilit
alt: Man in a blue suit stands confidently under stone arches.

body: Flexible, wearable, skin-like sensors developed by Zhenan Bao and her lab, 2024. The sensors, which use intrinsically stretchable transistors and integrated circuits, are designed to monitor human health, diagnose diseases, and provide opportunities for improved, autonomous treatments. Courtesy Bao Group.
heading: Advancing healthcare technology: Zhenan Bao's lab unveils flexible, wearable skin-like sensors for health monitoring and disease diagnosi
alt: Two gloved hands stretch a transparent, flexible electronic sheet with a grid pattern against a clear blue sky.

body: ABOVE: A human diver with Ocean One, a humanoid robot designed by Oussama Khatib, professor of computer science, 2016. Ocean One is fitted with pressure sensors on each hand that provide a human pilot with a sense of touch. The robot successfully retrieved artifacts from the wreck of La Lune, the flagship of King Louis XIV. LEFT: Ocean One exploring La Lune, which sank in the Mediterranean Ocean off the coast of France. Frederic Osada/DRASSM/Stanford.
heading: Exploring the deep: Ocean One, Khatib's revolutionary humanoid robot, retrieves artifacts from the wreck of La Lun
alt: A scuba diver extends a fist to an orange underwater robot.

body: Amy Zegart (left) interviews Jennifer Widom at the Stanford Emerging Technology Review launch, 2023. In their conversation, Widom discussed how the Review allows engineering and science faculty to engage in a larger dialogue about the broader implications of their work in a way that is accessible to lay audiences, including policymakers. Patrick Beaudouin/Hoover Institution.
heading: Bridging science and society: Jennifer Widom highlights the importance of the Stanford Emerging Technology Review at its launc
alt: Two women sit in armchairs on stage at a Stanford University event.

body: LEFT TO RIGHT: Zhenan Bao, Allison Okamura, and Jennifer Widom prior to the Stanford Emerging Technology Review launch event, 2023. The School of Engineering and the Hoover Institution jointly launched the Review to capture diverse views from across Stanford on recent technological breakthroughs. Hoover Institution/Patrick Beaudouin.
heading: Uniting voices in innovation: Zhenan Bao, Allison Okamura, and Jennifer Widom gather for the launch of the Stanford Emerging Technology Revie
alt: Three women in professional attire are engaged in a friendly conversation against a white wall.

body: Chemical engineer William Tarpeh, 2021. Tarpeh’s lab develops novel approaches to recover valuable resources from liquid waste streams, reducing environmental impact and enhancing sustainability. Rod Searcy.
heading: Championing sustainability: Chemical engineer William Tarpeh pioneers innovative resource recovery from liquid waste stream
alt: Smiling man in a brown blazer stands outdoors.

body: Exterior rendering of the Computing and Data Science building, opened in 2025. The building, nicknamed “CoDa,” is home to faculty from the Departments of Computer Science and Statistics, a cross-university data science initiative, and undergraduate programs in computer science, data science, and symbolic systems. Built jointly with the School of Humanities and Sciences, the building reflects the growing importance of data science in all areas of scholarship. LMN Architects.
heading: Architectural milestone: Stanford unveils the Computing and Data Science Building ('CoDa') to foster interdisciplinary innovation in data researc
alt: llustration of a building's exterior with glass facades and a cylindrical section.

body: Dean Jennifer Widom, center, with new graduate students at the Dean’s Welcome event, September 2024. Saul Bromberger/Stanford Engineering.
heading: Welcoming future innovators: Dean Jennifer Widom hosts new graduate students at Dean’s Welcome Even
alt: A diverse group of smiling individuals wearing red "Stanford Engineering" T-shirts wave at the camera.

body: Mechanical Engineering student, 1970. Stanford News Service.
heading: Engineering aspirations
alt: Researcher in a lab coat works intently on electronic components at a cluttered desk.
